docs.snippet: Inspired by Steven Soderbergh's ''Schizopolis,'' one Web site offers up some satirical banality....
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that everyone has had a day to suck in the Oscar news, and process the snubs and surprises, the Bagger would like to weigh in with her own analysis. Well, we'd like to, but it's a lot easier to link to this generic analysis, written a la Steven Soderbergh's "Schizopolis" ("generic greeting").
docs.abstract: Inspired by Steven Soderbergh's ''Schizopolis,'' one Web site offers up some satirical banality.

docs.snippet: While Christoph Waltz learned of his nomination from his publicists and managers, Jeremy Renner got the news while on live television....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nobody call sexism, please. Though we mostly heard from actresses in the aftermath of the Academy Awards announcements on Tuesday, the Baguette also spoke with a few actors, Christoph Waltz and Jeremy Renner, who were each nominated for playing a dedicated (and in one case, very evil) military man.
docs.abstract: While Christoph Waltz learned of his nomination from his publicists and managers, Jeremy Renner got the news while on live television.

byline.original: By MELENA RYZIK AND PAULA SCHWARTZ

docs.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Well, the Oscar nominations were announced today, you guys. Best-actor nominees included George Clooney for "Up in the Air," Jeremy Renner for "The Hurt Locker," and President Obama for the "State of the Union."

docs.snippet: BROWN--David, 93, acclaimed movie producer, author and journalist, passed away on Monday, February 1, 2010, at his home in Manhattan. Brown's legendary career as a movie producer and executive spanned six decades, included four Academy Award nomin...
docs.lead_paragraph: BROWN--David, 93, acclaimed movie producer, author and journalist, passed away on Monday, February 1, 2010, at his home in Manhattan. Brown's legendary career as a movie producer and executive spanned six decades, included four Academy Award nominations and produced smash box office hits like Oscar winners The Sting and Jaws, along with popular classics like Cocoon and Driving Miss Daisy. He was married for more than 50 years to Cosmopolitan magazine editor and author Helen Gurley Brown. Brown and his wife have been celebrated as anchors of both the Hollywood film and New York publishing communities. A public funeral will be held on Thursday, February 4 at 3:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.) in New York City.

docs.snippet: For a long time it seemed like films made about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan just weren't clicking with critics or audiences. But with "The Hurt Locker" tied at the top of the pack of Oscar nominations with "Avatar" and a win at Sundance for t...
docs.lead_paragraph: For a long time it seemed like films made about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan just weren't clicking with critics or audiences. But with "The Hurt Locker" tied at the top of the pack of Oscar nominations with "Avatar" and a win at Sundance for the Afghanistan documentary "Restrepo," movies are finally catching up to the stage, which has fared better in tackling the past eight years of conflict. There was "Stuff Happens," "Black Watch" and now "Time Stands Still," which stars Laura Linney as a photojournalist recuperating from severe injuries suffered while she was covering the war in Iraq and Brian d'Arcy James as her partner who suffered a breakdown there. The "thoughtful drama by Donald Margulies," writes Charles Isherwood, which also stars Alicia Silverstone and Eric Bogosian, "explores the relationship between two couples at a crucial juncture in their lives, when the desire to move forward clashes with the instinct to stay comfortably — or even uncomfortably — in place." The "flawless Manhattan Theater Club production" is directed by Daniel Sullivan, "with the leads giving performances of "complementary sensitivity and richness."

docs.snippet: In keeping with the golden statue theme, "Ajami," an Israeli film, one of five Oscar nominees for best foreign-language film, opens today in New York. The movie, takes its name from a rough neighborhood in Jaffa, a mostly Arab city just south of T...
docs.lead_paragraph: In keeping with the golden statue theme, "Ajami," an Israeli film, one of five Oscar nominees for best foreign-language film, opens today in New York. The movie, takes its name from a rough neighborhood in Jaffa, a mostly Arab city just south of Tel Aviv. "This particular urban conflict zone may be unfamiliar to most American viewers, but it bears a definite kinship to mean streets we know very well, at least from movies and television," writes A.O. Scott. "We could almost be in the Los Angeles of 'Colors' or 'Boyz N the Hood,' the Baltimore of 'The Wire' or the Rio de Janeiro of 'City of God.' " The movie, written and directed by Scandar Copti, an Israeli Arab, and Yaron Shani, who is Jewish, "is acutely insightful about the social divisions within Israel, but it examines them without scolding or sentimentality. There is no finger-pointing here, and no group hugging either. Instead there is an acute sense of just how deep and wide the schisms are, not just between Jews and Arabs, but also between Christians and Muslims, rich and poor, farmers and city dwellers, men and women, young and old and so on."
